comments.commentBody: Not bad, but it lacks analysis of what will happen when Biden jumps into the race.
Der Blingmeister's troops are driving all before them ... but where are they going?

replies.commentBody:
Apparently,35 % of Republicans are telling pollster they won't ,under any circumstance , vote for Trump if he's the GOP nominee .But if he's not,then many of his supporters will revolt,at the Convention .So,the GOP's so screwed!
It has this ol' Liberal smiling!

comments.commentBody:
As DJT's UNfavorable rating in aggregate polls continues to move toward 70% of the nation, with a favorable rating just north of 30%, the DNC must be very pleased with how this is shaping up.
Yet another Republican primary does in the field.

Tuesday, March 15: The Day the Marco Died.

Singin' bye, bye Mister Florida Guy,
Drove my fossil fuel guzzler to the panhandle but the panhandle was in a state of global warming-induced drought,
And good ol' pundits were drinkin' whiskey and rye,
Singin' this'll be the day the Marco dies.
Please let this come down to California. I just want to see that.

replies.commentBody: For every Republican who holds his nose and votes for Hillary, there will be a Democrat who holds her nose and votes for Trump.  Either way, all voters will be losers.  Vote for Sanders!

comments.commentBody: If the RNC steals the "will of the people" at the convention, it will be the end of the Republican Party.  I am a Republican and if the people's will is betrayed, I will hold my nose and vote for Hillary.

This is one of those "movie moments", when someone says "if you could go back in time and stop Hitler, would you do it?".  At this point, my biggest concern is not who I want to be elected, but rather who I do not want to be elected.  Someone, anyone, please stop Trump (Drumph)!

replies.commentBody: Capitalism generates rapid technological change. That is the main cause of jobs losses in manufacturing, not 'sending jobs overseas'. From 1945 through 1975, capital and labour shared the gains of technological change. Since then, with the weakening of trade unions in the private sector, capital reaps the profits while wages stagnate and inequality increases. With Republicans in Congress and GOP governors attacking trade unions, this trend will worsen. Both Trump and Sanders are opposed to free trade. But only Sanders supports strong unions.
Are you saying under-educated people are not qualified to vote?

comments.commentBody: Demagoguery in American politics is playing out in real time, as DJT taps into the under-educated, left-behind and angry white voters.  This group matches the gross number and collective fervor of Hispanic and Black voters across America. Short of bringing down all Americans and the world to their level of competence or incompetence, what's a workable solution in a globally competitive world? There's no hope for the USA to achieve at levels suitable for the lowest common denominator and to appease this group regardless of their numbers and volatile temperament.  Either we excel through innovations and productive growth or we will be run over by more capable workforce around the world.   Capitalism succeeds without gratitude for the strong or mercy for the weak but is the most effective & efficient method of allocating resources and creating value known to mankind. Lets truly make America great again, by encouraging, supporting and rewarding our highest achievers!

replies.commentBody: I agree with you completely, and you said it much more specifically than I did, below. Kasich hopefully will dampen Cruz's totals, too.

comments.commentBody: I'm convinced that *losing* Ohio is actually to Trump's advantage. This keeps Kasich in the race, splitting the anti-Trump vote going forward in subsequent winner-take-all races.

Let's stop and think for a moment of a President Ted Cruz, and the ramifications his presidency would absolutely entail for our country, as he makes no secret of his intentions. Do we want a nominee Cruz facing the Democrat nominee in November?

replies.commentBody:
I'm not convinced that a majority of "establishment" Republicans would prefer Cruz to Trump. Cruz has demonstrated over and over that he has extremely rigid views and will happily destroy the party or the government rather than compromise.

Trump, by contrast, states extreme (almost comically extreme) positions in his speeches, but repeatedly says he's willing to make deals. If I were a mainstream Republican, I wouldn't be delighted with either one, but I'd be more hopeful about getting along with Trump.

I agree with you Trump is the more moderate of the two. But, given the media hysteria about him, I don't think  establishment Republicans are willing to support Trump as their presidential candidate.  He hurts the Republican brand far more than Cruz does.

Ross, Trump will rout Cruz head-to-head. Cruz blew his chance by losing the South to Trump except for his home state of Texas. After today, the map gets much more favorable for Trump and much less so for Cruz. Do you like Cruz's chances in the big Northeast states still coming up? I sure don't. There is a big chunk of the Republican electorate that is populist but not that conservative. Cruz is too conservative for them.

comments.commentBody: If Trump wins both Florida and Ohio, that may be the end of Trump. It is then a contest between Trump and Cruz. Winner take all is not going to work to Trump's advantage in a two person race against Cruz if there is a a 50% anybody-but-Trump vote.

replies.commentBody: it's just typical beer commercial mentality-the same losers that watch Reality TV and thinks thats real and telling it like it is-the most easily manipulated of all the lemmings that is a Trump supporter-but no matter how much noise they make Trump will never be POTUS-both Hilarity and Bernie can beat him if the GOP ends up being total mohons and having Trump as their candidate-it's funny really watching the GOP implode after all their deception -however don't be fooled the 1% is backing Hilarity she is more of a good ol boy than than her white waspy counterparts and she seems rather entitled like the deal was struck when Obama went to office-he's the first black POTUS and the Hilary you will be the first woman POTUS-with the world knowing who controls the GOP it's time to shape shift again and now make the DNC according to Hilarity their trojan horse-obviously the Tea party was an epic fail for them-the ONLY SANE choice in 2016 is Mr. Sanders  FELL THE BERN!

comments.commentBody:
I keep thinking about the consistently stated reason Trump supporters regurgitate their bilious adoration, "He tells it like it is. He says what everyone is thinking." Who is "everyone" and what is "it"?

His "everyone" demographic is a rather narrow minded population trapped in a "back to the future" 1950s America. "It's" a "Leave It to Beaver" whitewash of life. They're not a population that believes in fact, faith, or the future. They want the past.

So, The Upshot, it matters not how you speculate if there'll be a contested GOP convention or not because there aren't enough Beaver Cleavers to hang a hanging chad. Trump is right, the electorate is energized, and more, not even the GOP will try to subterfuge a "yuge" voter turnout.

As was clearly shown on the Bill Maher Show, Donald Trump fits the classical definition of both a narcissist and a pyschopath.... hence Carson endorsing "both sides" of Trump. It is incumbent on all Republicans to repudiate Donald Trump. He is mentally unstable and a threat to the Republic.
Implicit here: best all around if Rubio left the race.

replies.commentBody:
You nailed it on the head. To be anti-establishment, Trump must act chaotically. Establishment acts predictably. "Establishment" got us in this "pickle" we're in. The "pickle" is that just about everything in politics is a double bind, and most politicians just keep double binding everything they touch to keep the dissonance at bay. Dissonance in themselves, and their constituents. Us.

You are dizzy because you are confused. Dissonance is typically led by confusion, which is a special subset of fear. Fear of the unknown, more specifically.

I believe Trump saw this dissonance, made an educated observation of the current levels of it, and then put a double bind-based strategy in place to tip it to his favor using the anti-establishment message to get it sold.

The counter strategy is simple: Anti-establishment and Presidents don't go together. Figure out how to double bind him back. I'm talking to you Bernie.

comments.commentBody:
I do not understand why this is a crucial day. Mr. Trump appears having clothes of Teflon. Every criticism on him deflects of him and wounding the Criticizer.
Because his Brand is anti-establishment and because establishment is guilty of making America Not Great, his pronouncements - by definition - make America Great Again; reality is irrelevant.
Welcome to a political world where down is up, left is right, and I am dizzy.
The only thing crucial happened over the last 12 years during which the Republican Party slept with the devil. Now the fruit of that marriage is grown up; incarnated in Donald Trump.

replies.commentBody: Or, ruin it entirely.  I am betting on ruining it, since he doesn't have a plan, just a lot of talking.
"Make America great again"?  There is nothing "great" about bullying.

Now there is a sentiment that actually could have been said by Germans in the 1930's.  Hitler did make Germany great again and then, in the words of one German after the war, "he went too far. But frankly, unlike Germany, the notion that the United States somehow needs to be restored to greatness is a bit silly.

comments.commentBody: Like Bill Clinton said, "Trump is a master brander." Trump is a brilliant strategist and tactician. He did not become a multi-billionaire by being stupid. His competitoin have consistently underestimated him to each of their own perils. Trump came into the race for the highest office in the land, having had no previous experience, running for or holding political office, and he went straight to the top. He has proven to be a very fast learner. He is not the candidate today he was yesterday, and he will be yet a different candidate tomorrow. His ability at winning in new venues has always been legend. What he is doing in this election is positively mind boggling. His Republican opponents are toast. He will stomp whoever the Dems put up, and when he gets into the Oval Office his peers at the helms of the various countries of the world had best take heed. It will be a war of America first, and he will be taking no prisoners. Trump will indeed make America great again.

If the GOP uses the "nuclear" (or nucular) option to deny Trump the nomination at the convention if he brings in 1,100 or so delegates, the eventual nominee is likely to make Trump supporters so angry that those votes will stay home. It's one thing to lose fair and square, another to be ripped off. Realistically if the GOP hopes to win in November they better be thinking of how to  keep Trump's haul to under four digits. And that seems near impossible at this point.

replies.commentBody: Why not Trump? What has he done that makes him worse than the other candidates?

Why? Trump is by far the most progressive candidate on the Republican side. If he's nominated, he may well run to the left of Hillary targeting working class voters.

What Trump has demonstrated is that much of the Republican "base" is not really all that ideologically conservative. Many are racist, but that is not surprising given the Republican southern strategy has been built on race. Trump is being a lot more explicit in his appeals to race, but the other candidates make the same appeal using polite code words. Its plausible this election will be the start of a major political realignment along economic divisions, rather than traditional ideology.

Tyler ... do you really "not get it?" Trump's running a fascist personality-cult campaign. He has no rational policies. "Deals" and "yuuuuge" are not even plausible slogans.

Trump's real message is "burn it down."

comments.commentBody: Anyone but trump.

While the specter of Trump losing is appealing, the victory would feel a bit empty with Cruz or Kasich, though especially Cruz, taking the lead. It's russian roulette but we forgot to stop loading after one bullet.
It would be nice if a sitting Governor could win his own State!
Even if Trump dropped out now, the other delegates have acted so viciously toward Trump they wouldn't get my vote.
